name: hydrazinecarboxamide, n-phenyl-
Reason: 1,3-diphenylpropane has a melting point around 100°C. The presence of a phenyl group generally increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, which can raise it by approximately +20°C. The carboxamide group introduces a polar carbonyl interaction, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and raise the melting point by approximately +20°C. The hydrazine group introduces a strong dipole, which can increase the melting point by approximately +50°C.
